channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Shipping Bottlenecks in Europe Send a Warning Signal to US, Asia
item.description: Port congestion is worsening at key gateways in northern Europe and other hubs, according to a new report which suggests trade wars could spread maritime disruptions to Asia and the US and push up shipping rates.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: The container terminal at Bremerhaven port in Bremerhaven, Germany, on April 22, 2025.

item.title: Fed to Take in Stride Another Month of Tame Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve may take comfort that tariffs have yet to materially boost official inflation readings, but policymakers will continue to suggest interest rates are on hold until they better understand the coming impact of US trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Stocks soared after President Donald Trump said he’d pause some tariffs on dozens of countries for 90 days, signaling a tentative reprieve in trade hostilities that has wiped out trillions from global markets and ignited fears of a US recession.

item.title: Ken Rogoff on How Crypto Is Cutting Into the Dollar’s Hegemony
item.description: From the International Monetary Fund to the Federal Reserve, Kenneth Rogoff has spent years inside the institutions that helped shape the dollar-led global economic order.
item.dc:creator: Vildana Hajric

item.title: Trump Risks US Consumer Discontent With His Tariffs, Poll Shows
item.description: President Donald Trump’s trade agenda is leaving consumers worried about their household costs.
item.dc:creator: Claire Ballentine, Shawn Donnan

item.title: Monsoon’s Earliest Onset in India Since 2009 Boosts Crop Outlook
item.description: The monsoon, a weather phenomenon that waters more than half of India’s farmland, reached the subcontinent before the usual time, boosting crop outlook and raising hopes the nation will lift remaining curbs on exports of farm goods.
item.dc:creator: Atul Prakash, Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: Workers wear raincoats at a farm in Karnataka, India, on May 23.

item.title: Canada’s Macklem Says US Tariffs ‘Biggest Headwind,’ NYT Reports
item.description: Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem called President Donald Trump’s tariffs the “biggest headwind” for the country, given the close integration of the two economies, according to the New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Shiyin Chen

media:content.media:description: Tiff Macklem, governor of the Bank of Canada, during a news conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of Canada is warning that the ongoing tariff dispute has "rattled markets" and increases the risk of "disorderly" sell-offs that would test the country's financial system.

item.title: Why Asia May Invest More in Its Own Backyard
item.description: What’s old is new again, as the saying goes. In the years following the 2008 global financial crisis, economies and investors had to contend with (or were happy to enjoy) dramatically lower interest rates than those that prevailed prior to what came to be known as the Great Recession.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: The Sunshine 60 building, top center, and other buildings in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Feb. 17.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: Long-Term Bond Yields Soar Around the World
item.description: Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: HONG KONG, CHINA - AUGUST 12: Pedestrians cross a road in a shopping district on August 12, 2024 in Hong Kong, China. Hong Kong has one of the highest population densities in the world, with approximately 7,140 people per square kilometer as of 2024, reflecting its status as a major urban center. As global population growth continues, urban areas like Hong Kong highlight the challenges of accommodating increasing numbers of residents in limited space, prompting discussions on sustainable urban development and resource management. (Photo by Anthony Kwan/Getty Images)

item.title: Indonesia to Cut Transport and Power Prices to Spur Consumption
item.description: Indonesia will cut transport and power costs and deliver other stimulus in June and July in an effort to boost household spending and rekindle economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

media:content.media:description: Morning commuters get off a train at Tebet railway station in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Feb. 15, 2024. Indonesian stocks jumped in early trading as traders bet on policy continuity after Defense Minister Prabowo Subianto declared victory in Wednesday's presidential vote.

item.title: How Britain’s Stats Geeks Lost Track of the Economy
item.description: Just before midday on May 9, employees of the Office for National Statistics were summoned to an urgent call.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Isobel Finkel

media:content.media:description: Commuters cross London Bridge in view of Tower Bridge in London, UK, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. The Office of National Statistics will release the latest labour market figures on Tuesday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Pakistan’s Next Funding Review in Second Half of 2025, IMF Says
item.description: Pakistan has reaffirmed its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the International Monetary Fund will conduct its next funding review in the second half of this year, the multilateral agency said.
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: A vendor arranges his wares at a market in Karachi, Pakistan, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Pakistan is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Dec 1. Photographer: Asim Hafeez/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Forces Switzerland to Question Its Love for Farmers
item.description: Switzerland’s bid for a US trade deal risks sparking a showdown with one political force at least as feisty as President Donald Trump: its own farmers.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Mountain pasture in Switzerland. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Signals Intent to Reach US Tariff Deal by G-7 in June
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa indicated his aim to resolve tariff talks in time for a June meeting between US President Donald Trump and Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba following Trump’s surprise pivot to allow a partnership between two of the countries’ steelmakers.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa, Japan’s chief tariff negotiator, speaks to reporters at Tokyo’s Haneda airport on May 23, 2025, before departing for the United States for the third round of tariff talks with U.S. officials. (Photo by Kyodo News via Getty Images)

item.title: Meloni Wins Hope of Moody’s Italy Upgrade From Brink of Junk
item.description: Italy’s credit score is skewed toward a potential upgrade at Moody’s Ratings, which has just joined rivals in rewarding Premier Giorgia Meloni’s push for fiscal restraint.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Craig Stirling

item.title: Trump Threatens EU, Smartphones as Tariff Rhetoric Escalates
item.description: President Donald Trump dug in on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on the European Union and said a potential 25% charge on smartphones would apply to all foreign-made devices, in the latest escalation of a trade war that is rattling markets and confusing businesses.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Skylar Woodhouse, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Paraguay Holds Key Rate at 6% Amid Steady Inflation Expectations
item.description: Paraguay’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 6%, citing stable long-term inflation expectations congruent with its target.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

item.title: Chile Finance Chief Wants to Unlock Billions in New Investments
item.description: Chile’s government is readying legislation to unlock billions of dollars of investments by speeding up the approval process, following years of complaints over excessive red tape, Finance Minister Mario Marcel said.
item.dc:creator: Antonia Mufarech, Matthew Malinowski

item.title: Bessent Says Trump Paused Sovereign Wealth Fund to Focus on Debt
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the Trump administration paused plans to create a sovereign wealth fund as the president prioritizes paying down the national debt.
item.dc:creator: Marion Halftermeyer, Daniel Flatley

item.title: Bessent Sees Easing Capital Rule on Treasuries This Summer
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that US regulators this summer may ease a rule that’s served as a constraint on banks’ trading in the $29 trillion Treasuries market.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Ghana Holds Key Rate as Cedi Rally Seen Taming Inflation
item.description: Ghana’s central bank kept its key interest rate on hold to maintain downward pressure on inflation, which is expected to get a boost from the West African nation’s world-beating currency.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh, Moses Mozart Dzawu

media:content.media:description: A customer makes a purchase at the Makola market in Accra, Ghana.
